subject: Re: testing abstract methods
msgSnippet: Hi Chandima, there is a very simple pattern to solve your problem. You can use it to test abstract classes as interfaces as well. Imagine you have a Recycable
messageBody:
Hi Chandima,

there is a very simple pattern to solve your problem. You can use it
to test abstract classes as interfaces as well. Imagine you have a
Recycable Class that has a recycable()-method. Because a Recycable is
a very abstract thing you simply create an AbstractRecycableTest like
this:

public abstract class AbstractRecycableTest extends TestCase {

private Recycable recycable = null;

public abstract Recycable createRecycable();

public void setUp() {
this.recycable = this.createRecycable();
}

public final void testIsRecycled() {
...
this.recycable.recycle();
...
}

public final void testRecycleToComponents() {
...
this.recycable.recycle();
...
}
}

Declare an abstract creation-method for your concrete recycable, that
creates for example a tetrapack or bottle.

Then create your concrete Testcases:

public class RecycableFlugzeugTest extends AbstractRecycableTest {

@Override
public final Recycable createRecycable() {
Flugzeug flugzeug = new Flugzeug();
return flugzeug;
}
}

public class RecycableBottleTest extends AbstractRecycableTest {

@Override
public final Recycable createRecycable() {
Bottle bottle = new Bottle(1.0);
return bottle;
}
}

This are the classes that can be run by the Testrunner.

In this general manner you are not only able to test that the
recycle()-method has been implemented. More over you are able to
ensure that the recycle()-method meets the requirements and that for
each implementing or inheriting class! So you only have to write a
Recycable[...]Test and implement a creation-method to ensure that your
class under test is really recycable.
Maybe somebody has the idea to inherit the RecycableMilkBottleTest
from your RecycableBottleTest and tries to override your
creation-method in an unexpected way; so don't forget to make each
creation method final to prevent this dangerous overriding.
